text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion,

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear. 

I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.  I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable. A lot of the female population are in sports, and trying to run or work out with the large pads the school provides can be really uncomfortable and embarrassing when others can see the bulky item.

I think that the school should provide tampons as well.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.  I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable. A lot of the female population are in sports, and trying to run or work out with the large pads the school provides can be really uncomfortable and embarrassing when others can see the bulky item.

I think that the school should provide tampons as well. Not every girl likes the feel of a pad, and I think it is like wearing a diaper. There should be options for the students depending upon preference. These aren't luxury items, here. They are basic things that the female students should have access to without having to leave class with a bloody emergency, or go to the office to beg the nurse for the item.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.  I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable. A lot of the female population are in sports, and trying to run or work out with the large pads the school provides can be really uncomfortable and embarrassing when others can see the bulky item.

I think that the school should provide tampons as well. Not every girl likes the feel of a pad, and I think it is like wearing a diaper. There should be options for the students depending upon preference. These aren't luxury items, here. They are basic things that the female students should have access to without having to leave class with a bloody emergency, or go to the office to beg the nurse for the item. 

I think that the school should provide these items because it is a basic necessity for the female students.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.  I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable. A lot of the female population are in sports, and trying to run or work out with the large pads the school provides can be really uncomfortable and embarrassing when others can see the bulky item.

I think that the school should provide tampons as well. Not every girl likes the feel of a pad, and I think it is like wearing a diaper. There should be options for the students depending upon preference. These aren't luxury items, here. They are basic things that the female students should have access to without having to leave class with a bloody emergency, or go to the office to beg the nurse for the item. 

I think that the school should provide these items because it is a basic necessity for the female students. Everything costs money these days, and honestly, some students simply don't have anything extra in their families. It really isn't about handing these out in bulk, but having the school provide them for emergencies or when a student begins her period on a day she didn't expect to. It is inconvenient to have to search out an adult to get a feminine product, and awkward when all you can find are male teachers. Most of the athletic coaches are my girls' schools are men, and both of my daughters have called me to bring them pads because they were too embarrassed to ask the coach for one. There should be no reason that this is happening.

The only way these items are different is that the male students don't need them. Not sure if that is the reason they still aren't readily available or not. It does make me wonder if the boys needed these items, would they be in abundance?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty”? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, schools should provide these items to the female students. I haven't experienced this myself, but I have been in situations where I had to ask a fellow student for a pad. The only thing the schools have had available for decades (from when I was a teen to now when my daughters are in school) are the cheap, crappy large pads. These are really inappropriate for young girls since they don't fit well in their underwear.  I think it's important for girls to have the option of using a pad that fits well and is comfortable. A lot of the female population are in sports, and trying to run or work out with the large pads the school provides can be really uncomfortable and embarrassing when others can see the bulky item.

I think that the school should provide tampons as well. Not every girl likes the feel of a pad, and I think it is like wearing a diaper. There should be options for the students depending upon preference. These aren't luxury items, here. They are basic things that the female students should have access to without having to leave class with a bloody emergency, or go to the office to beg the nurse for the item. 

I think that the school should provide these items because it is a basic necessity for the female students. Everything costs money these days, and honestly, some students simply don't have anything extra in their families. It really isn't about handing these out in bulk, but having the school provide them for emergencies or when a student begins her period on a day she didn't expect to. It is inconvenient to have to search out an adult to get a feminine product, and awkward when all you can find are male teachers. Most of the athletic coaches are my girls' schools are men, and both of my daughters have called me to bring them pads because they were too embarrassed to ask the coach for one. There should be no reason that this is happening.

The only way these items are different is that the male students don't need them. Not sure if that is the reason they still aren't readily available or not. It does make me wonder if the boys needed these items, would they be in abundance? I absolutely think these items should be required by school. Giving the girls tokens of some sort if the school wanted to keep a machine in the girls bathrooms and locker rooms would be an idea. Each girl could get a certain number of tokens every month to access the machines and get what she needed. I have been to schools where there were pad and tampon machines in the girl's areas, but they cost a quarter to purchase. Honestly, what student is really carrying around change to buy these?

This is a basic need that females have to deal with every month. It already sucks enough without having to go and beg for a pad or tampon when you are having a crisis and bleeding in your underwear. There is no valid reason in my mind for the schools not to provide these items.
